newsitem.title: USA: CBOT soyoil expiry seen calm despite open interest.
newsitem.headline: CBOT soyoil expiry seen calm despite open interest.

text.p: Tuesday's expiry of Chicago Board of Trade October soyoil and soymeal contracts will likely go off quietly despite a recent increase in soyoil open interest, traders and analysts said.
"I don't think it's going to be too wild," said a cash-connected analyst. "The people who had to get out, got out today."
CBOT October soyoil and soymeal contracts expire at 1201 CDT Tuesday.
Open interest in October soyoil increased by nine lots on Friday to 619 lots, CBOT reported. But traders downplayed the increase saying the total remained small.
"You've got some funds short in the October (soyoil) and there was a little export business done," said one floor trader, explaining the increase in activity. "I don't think it's significant at all."
Open interest in soymeal fell by 452 lots to 1,262 as of Friday, CBOT reported.
Funds were said to be holding long positions in soymeal but many liquidated those on Monday, pit sources said.
CBOT price action supported that contention as October soyoil closed 0.09 cent a lb higher while soymeal ended $4.70 per ton lower.
Commercials likely account for the remaining open interest in soyoil, the cash-connected analyst said.
"Commercials can ride past the last trading day," he said, noting commercials likely intend to make or take delivery.
CBOT registrations of soyoil in deliverable locations increased by 28 lots late Friday, bringing the total as of Monday to 3,510 lots.
"I did see we had a little more oil registered," the analyst said. "Commercials may have posted that, so open interest would increase at that point."
